comment: A rare situation in the King's Gambit - all eight pawns of both side are still on the board. Rubinstein employed what was then a new plan for the King's Gambit Declined od developing his king's knigth at e7. From the opening Black achieved an equal game, and the superficially acrive 9. f5? led merely to difficulties for White. By energetic play 9...Nd4! and 13... d5! Black seized the initiative, and the inaccurate 14.0-0 (14.Qf2 was correct, freeing the c3 square for the knight) led Alapin to an umpleasant ending. White's knight at a3 stands badly, his e4 pawn may become weak, and he appears to have no prospects at all of active play. Black has fine possibilities of play both on the queenside along the a-file and in the centre alon the d-file.
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake made by the player, emphasizing the strategic downfall of White and the potential for Black to seize the initiative.
